head.supplied: 28 Arnold Street, South Yarra ¶ March 27th 1897 ¶ Charles A. Topp, Esq., M.A. ¶ Under Secretary ¶ Sir, —...

div.p: From William Potter to Charles Topp
F97/4027, unit 972, VPRS 3992/P inward registered correspondence, VA 475 Chief Secretary's Department, Public Record Office, Victoria.

Referring to your letter (No. 1309) of the 23rd instant, with regard to the Gratuity of £600 made by the Government to the Executors of the late Baron Sir Ferdinand Von Mueller,
Letter not found. However, on 23 March 1897, Topp minuted: 'Saw the U. T. [Under Treasurer] today Write to Mr Potter referring to our interview yesterday and say that the conditions under which the gratuity of £600 is to be paid are (1) that the Executors forward a schedule giving details of the manner in which the sum is to be expended with an engagement that the money when paid shall be so expended and that all books office furniture specimens &c the property of the Government be delivered to the Curator of the Museum'. I have the honour on their behalf, to furnish you with the attached "Schedule giving details of the manner in which the sum is to be expended," and also to give you an undertaking that the money when paid, shall be so expended.

The books, office furniture, &c mentioned in your communication have been, as far as in my power to do so, gathered together, and will be delivered to the Curator of the Herbarium on Monday next, March 29.
The promised material was not delivered. On 13 August 1897, the Under Treasurer, R. Rogers, minuted to Topp: 'The Revd Mr Potter has drawn only £450 on a/c of the Estate of the late Baron von Mueller The balance of the vote will lapse unless drawn on or before the 31st Inst.' Topp responded: 'Yes, but he has to hand over the books belonging to the Govt before he can draw it; but bring under notice again in 10 days'.
In a minute marked ' Urgent ', Topp wrote on 24 August: 'Referred to the Under Treasurer. I have paid the Executors £450 out of the £600 granted as a gratuity to the Executors of the late Baron Von Mueller; but have not yet paid the balance (£150) pending delivery by the Trustees of about £300 work of books belonging to the Government. I have repeatedly urged Mr Potter to deliver them but he has not yet done so though he does not dispute the fact that they belong to the Government. I shall be glad to know whether I shall let the £150 lapse if Mr Potter does not deliver the Governments property before the end of the month'. Rogers responded on 26 August: 'Sir George Turner suggests that you advise the Executors of the position'.
MS annotation: '£150 paid into Trust Fund 31.8.97.'
Permit me to add that the Executors appreciate very highly the favour of the Cabinet, and the uniform courtesy experienced from yourself.
